narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Lots of interesting readings. Sometimes a little too much to digest, but we didn't have to do everything in depth to be able to participate meaningfully in class. Weekly assignment encouraged us to think critically and ask questions about current research.
there is so much that goes into changing one's mind, it's incredible! I loved each topic we covered in class!

This class is a great overview of different topics about how we change our minds. Broadly and initially, readings and discussions focus on persuasion, visual information, first impression formation and reversal, etc., and later on, these concepts are applied to topics like bias reduction, misinformation, conspiracy theories, politics, and more.
Ability to critically break down psychology papers, knowledge of implicit and explicit mechanisms for impression updating
Learnt about motivations and methods of changing minds
I learned the the main theories behind why, how, and what causes people to change (or not change) their minds through topics such as fake news, conspiracy theories, and belief updating.
A broad overview of the ways that our minds can change about people and concepts. Digging into papers and evaluating their strengths and weaknesses was a major task of the class

So much about the literature of changing the mind and implicit/explicit judgements/biases. Most importantly, I learned how to think critically and form new questions our of old questions, and express complex and unsure thoughts or in a concise and coherent way.

Learned a lot about many different aspects of the psychology of changing your mind. We talked about everything from prejudice and racism to fake news. Developed my critical skill of reading of psychology papers.
overview of social psychology literature in persuasion and opinion change

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I loved it!

amazing class! loved the class discussions- really helped broaden my understanding of the readings and just our minds in general, such as how biases and norms influence us. I can now apply so much that I've learned to my life!

This course is well-structured for student comprehension and conversation. The structure of requiring reading responses (required to submit 6 on weeks of your choosing), leading class discussions (twice per student per semester), and the final paper allowed for engagement with the material in a way that felt productive rather than tedious or boring.
The structure of class time was monotonous week-to-week, but the topics were very interesting.
I can't think of a way this course could be improved. Melissa is fantastic!
The content was very interesting but sometimes hard to get through papers

This course was very well organized and I genuinely looked forward to coming to class every week. I liked that students got the chance to lead discussions and ask questions based on peers' responses, and all of the reading materials were super interesting and relevant.

Strengths - Lots of great readings, great discussion format, never too much work.

Weaknesses - Feedback on work could have been clearer (didn't receive any)
Strengths: engages every student, fascinating literature, no assignment felt like busy work
We could have gotten more instructions or feedback about the final project.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: discussions were great, even over zoom!
The discussion format of the class worked well for the virtual world!
The discussion thread posts on Canvas worked well to facilitate thought before class, and the class felt pretty normal considering we were on Zoom.
Professor Ferguson was incredibly kind and accommodating.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If they are a psych major, yes. I think if it wasn't an interest, it would have felt like too much. For me, it was great though.
YES TAKE IT! for thesis or not thesis! really amazing new psych material that I had previously never encountered but learned so much about

I'd highly recommend this course to anyone interested in social psychology or the topics discussed in the course, as this class offers such insight into how we interact with others, information, and ourselves.

I would absolutely recommend this course. If you are curious about how attitudes are formed and shaped, take this class. We went over about 1/4 as much material as a lecture, but we read individual studies very closely. Melissa is energetic and kind!
Definitely. Professor Ferguson is wonderful and knows this field so well that she is both clear and humble about how to think through and interrogate evidence.
Yes the content was interesting and Melissa was great

Yes, please take this course! I learned so much about highly relevant topics (fake news, conspiracy theories) that I would never have found out about otherwise. Professor Ferguson is the kindest and so knowledgeable about the field!

Yes, definitely. Once you have a a solid PSYC background, this class is a relatively easy but thorough deep dive into this psychological concept of changing one's mind. Discussions made learning very easy, and participation is geared toward introverts (like me) having an equal shot at participating. Loved the class.
yes!!! so interesting
Yes! It was a great class and the topics we talked about were super interesting.
